column1: Winchester is an independent city located in the northern portion of the Commonwealth of Virginia
column2: United States. It is the county seat of Frederick County
column3: although the two are separate jurisdictions. The Bureau of Economic Analysis combines the city of Winchester with surrounding Frederick County for statistical purposes. As of the 2010 census
column6: its population is an estimated 28
column7: 078.Winchester is the principal city of the Winchester
column10: which is a part of the Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area. Winchester is home to Shenandoah University and the Museum of the Shenandoah Valley.

column1: Indigenous peoples lived along the waterways of present-day Virginia for thousands of years before European contact. Archeological
column2: linguistic and anthropological studies have provided insights into their cultures. Though little is known of specific tribal movements before European contact
column3: the Shenandoah Valley area
column4: considered a sacred common hunting ground
column5: appears by the 17th century to have been controlled mostly by the local Iroquoian-speaking groups
column6: including the Senedo and Sherando.

column1: The Algonquian-speaking Shawnee began to challenge the Iroquoians for the hunting grounds later in that century. The explorers Batts and Fallam in 1671 reported the Shawnee were contesting with the Iroquoians for control of the valley and were losing. During the later Beaver Wars
column2: the powerful Iroquois Confederacy from New York (particularly Seneca from the western part of the territory) subjugated all tribes in the frontier region west of the Fall Line.

column1: By the time European settlers arrived in the Shenandoah Valley around 1729
column2: the Shawnee were the principal occupants in the area around Winchester. During the first decade of white settlement
column3: the valley was also a conduit and battleground in a bloody intertribal war between the Seneca and allied Algonquian Lenape from the north
column5: the Siouan Catawba in the Carolinas. The Iroquois Six Nations finally ceded their nominal claim to the Shenandoah Valley at the Treaty of Lancaster (1744). The treaty also established the right of colonists to use the Indian Road
column6: later known as the Great Wagon Road.

column1: The father of the historical Shawnee chief Cornstalk had his court at Shawnee Springs (near today's Cross Junction
column2: Virginia) until 1754. In 1753
column3: on the eve of the French and Indian War (Seven Years' War)
column4: messengers came to the Shawnee from tribes further west
column5: inviting them to leave the Valley and cross the Alleghenies
column6: which they did the following year. The Shawnee settled for some years in the Ohio Country before being forced by the US government under Indian Removal in the 1830s to remove to Indian Territory.

column1: Winchester had a notable role as a frontier city in those early times.  The Governor of Virginia
column2: as well as the young military commander George Washington
column3: met in the town with their Iroquois allies (called the "Half-Kings")
column4: to coordinate maneuvers against the French and their Native American allies during the French and Indian War.

column1: French Jesuit expeditions may have first entered the valley as early as 1606
column2: as the explorer Samuel de Champlain made a crude map of the area in 1632. The first confirmed exploration of the northern valley was by the explorer John Lederer
column3: who viewed the region from the current Fauquier and Warren County line on August 26
column4: 1670. In 1705 the Swiss explorer Louise Michel and in 1716 Governor Alexander Spotswood did more extensive mapping and surveying.

column2: Governor William Gooch promoted settlement by issuing large land grants. Robert "King" Carter
column3: manager of the Lord Fairfax proprietorship
column5: 000 acres (810 km2). This combination of events directly precipitated an inrush of settlers from Pennsylvania and New York
column6: made up of a blend of Quakers and German and Scots-Irish homesteaders
column7: many of them new immigrants. The Scots-Irish comprised the most numerous group of immigrants from the British Isles before the American Revolutionary War.

column1: The settlement of Winchester began as early as 1729
column2: when Quakers such as Abraham Hollingsworth migrated up (south) the Great Valley along the long-traveled Indian Path (later called the Great Wagon Road by the colonists) from Pennsylvania.  He and others began to homestead on old Shawnee campgrounds. Tradition holds that the Quakers purchased several tracts on Apple-pie Ridge from the natives
column3: who did not disturb those settlements.The first German settler appears to have been Jost Hite in 1732
column5: including some Scots-Irish. Though Virginia was an Anglican colony
column6: Governor William Gooch had a tolerant policy on religion. The availability of land grants brought in many religious families
column8: 000 m2) plots through the sponsorship of fellow-religious grant purchasers and speculators. As a result
column9: the Winchester area became home to some of the oldest Presbyterian
column11: Lutheran and Anglican churches in the valley. The first Lutheran worship was established by Rev. John Casper Stoever Jr.
column12: and Alexander Ross established Hopewell Meeting for the Quakers. By 1736
column13: Scots-Irish built the Opequon Presbyterian Church in Kernstown.

column1: A legal fight erupted in 1735 when Thomas Fairfax
column2: Sixth Lord Fairfax came to Virginia to claim his land grant. It included "all the land in Virginia between the Rappahannock and the Potomac rivers"
column3: an old grant from King Charles II which overlapped and included Frederick County. It took some time for land titles to be cleared among early settlers.

column1: By 1738 these settlements became known as Frederick Town. The county of Frederick was carved out of Orange County. The first government was created
column2: consisting of a County Court as well as the Anglican Frederick Parish (for purposes of tax collection). Colonel James Wood
column3: an immigrant from Winchester
column5: was the first court clerk and had been a surveyor for Orange County
column6: Virginia. He contracted for his own home Glen Burnie homstead around 1737
column7: and it may have been used for early government business. Wood laid out 26 half-acre (2
column8: 000 m²) lots in 1744. The County Court held its first session on November 11
column10: where James Wood served until 1760. Lord Fairfax
column11: understanding that possession is 9/10ths of the law
column12: built a home here (in present-day Clarke County) in 1748.

column2: the Virginia House of Burgesses granted the fourth city charter in Virginia to 'Winchester' as Frederick Town was renamed after Colonel Wood's birthplace in England. In 1754
column3: Abraham Hollingsworth built the local residence called Abram's Delight
column4: which served as the first local Quaker meeting house. George Washington spent a good portion of his young life in Winchester helping survey the Fairfax land grant for Thomas Fairfax
column5: Sixth Lord Fairfax
column6: as well as performing surveying work for Colonel Wood. In 1758 Wood added 158 lots to the west side of town. In 1759 Thomas Lord Fairfax contributed 173 more lots to the south and east.

column1: General Edward Braddock's expeditionary march to Fort Duquesne crossed through this area in 1755 on the way to Fort Cumberland. Knowing the area well from work as a surveyor
column2: George Washington accompanied General Braddock as his aide-de-camp. Resident Daniel Morgan joined Braddock's Army as a wagoner on its march to Pennsylvania.
on land granted by James Wood
column3: Colonel George Washington designed and began constructing Fort Loudoun
column5: 860 m2) in present-day downtown Winchester on North Loudoun Street. Fort Loudoun was occupied and manned with guns until the start of the American Revolutionary War.

column2: a jail was built in Winchester. It occasionally held Quakers from many parts of Virginia who protested the French and Indian War and refused to pay taxes to the Anglican parish. While their cousins in Pennsylvania dominated politics there
column3: Virginia was an Anglican colony and did not tolerate pacifism well. The strong Quaker tradition of pacifism against strong Virginia support for this war and the next
column4: led to long-term stifling of the Quaker population. Winchester became a gateway to Quaker settlements further west; by the mid-19th century
column5: the Quaker population was a small minority here.

column2: at the age of 26
column3: Colonel George Washington was elected to represent Frederick County to the House of Burgesses. Daniel Morgan later served as a ranger protecting the borderlands of Virginia against Indian raids
column4: returning to Winchester in 1759. Following the war
column5: from 1763 to 1774 Daniel Morgan served in Captain Ashby's company and defended Virginia against Pontiac's Rebellion and Shawnee Indians in the Ohio valley (that part now in West Virginia).

column2: the Virginia House of Burgesses chose local resident and French and Indian War veteran Daniel Morgan to raise a company of militia to support General George Washington's efforts during the Siege of Boston. He led the 96 men of "Morgan's Sharpshooters" from Winchester on July 14
column3: 1775 and marched to Boston in 21 days. Morgan
column5: and others also performed duties in holding captured prisoners of war
column6: particularly Hessian soldiers.

column1: Hessian soldiers were known to walk to the high ridge north and west of town
column2: where they could purchase and eat apple pies made by the Quakers. The ridge became affectionately known as Apple Pie Ridge. The Ridge Road built before 1751 leading north from town was renamed Apple Pie Ridge Road. The local farmers found booming business in feeding the Virginia Militia and fledgling volunteer American army.
the town's first newspapers
column3: The Gazette and The Centinel
column4: were established. Daniel Morgan continued his public service
column5: being elected to one term in the U.S. House of Representatives (1797–1799).

column1: Winchester and the surrounding area were the site of numerous battles during the American Civil War
column2: as the Confederate and Union armies strove to control that portion of the Shenandoah Valley. Seven major battlefields are in the original Frederick County:
March 23
May 25
June 13–15
July 24
September 19
column3: 1864Near the city of Winchester:

column1: The Battle of Cool Spring at Snicker's Gap
column2: July 17–18
September 3–4

column1: The Battle of Belle Grove (or Cedar Creek)
column2: October 19
column3: 1864Winchester was a key strategic position for the Confederate States Army during the war. It was an important operational objective in Gen Joseph E. Johnston's and Col Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson's defense of the Shenandoah Valley in 1861
column5: the Gettysburg Campaign of 1863
column6: and the Valley Campaigns of 1864. Including minor cavalry raids and patrols
column8: historians claim that Winchester changed hands as many as 72 times and 13 times in one day. Battles raged along Main Street at points in the war. Union General Sheridan and Stonewall Jackson located their headquarters just one block apart at times.

column1: At the north end of the lower Shenandoah Valley
column2: Winchester was a base of operations for major Confederate invasions into the Northern United States. At times the attacks threatened the capital of Washington
column3: D.C. The town served as a central point for troops conducting major raids against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad
column5: and turnpike and telegraph paths along those routes and the Potomac River Valley. For instance
column7: Stonewall Jackson removed 56 locomotives and over 300 railroad cars
column9: from the B&O Railroad. His attack closed down the B&O's main line for ten months. Much of the effort to transport this equipment by horse and carriage centered in Winchester.

Dr. Hunter McGuire was Chief Surgeon of the Second Jackson's" Corps of the Army of Northern Virginia. He laid the foundations for the future Geneva conventions regarding the treatment of medical doctors during warfare. Winchester served as a major center for Confederate medical operations
column10: particularly after the Battle of Sharpsburg in 1862 and the Battle of Gettysburg in 1863.

column1: Winchester was the first city south of the Potomac River to install electric light. In 1917 the Winchester and Western Railroad connected Winchester with Rock Enon Springs
column2: moving both vacationers and supplies to the resort that is now Camp Rock Enon with far greater speed. Winchester is the location of the bi-annual N-SSA national competition keeping the tradition of Civil War era firearms alive. A three-block section of downtown Loudoun Street was closed to vehicular traffic in the 1970s and is a popular pedestrian area featuring many boutiques and cafes. The street was repaved with brick and landscaped in 2013. Apple Blossom Mall opened in 1982. In 1983
column3: a tire dump in the area containing over seven million tires burned for nine months
column4: polluting nearby areas with lead and arsenic. The location was cleaned up as a  Superfund project from 1983 to 2002.

Winchester is the location of the annual Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival
column2: which has existed since 1924. It is usually held during the first weekend in May.  The festival includes a carnival
column3: firework show
column5: several dances and parties
column6: and a coronation where the Apple Blossom Queen is crowned. Local school systems and many businesses close the Friday of Apple Blossom weekend.Winchester has more than 20 different "artistic" apples that are made of various materials including wood
column9: and paint. These apples were created in 2005 by occupants of the city
column10: and were placed at a specific location at the artists' request after being auctioned off. For example
column11: a bright red apple with a large stethoscope attached to it was placed beside a much-used entrance to the Winchester Medical Center.

column1: Winchester was home to Capitol Record's East Coast Pressing Plant. Capitol Records Distribution Corporation announced in 1968 the purchasing of land in Winchester
column2: Va for a new record processing plant. Along with this plant they built several houses
column3: bought a few small business and later built a tape production plant. The Winchester plant began construction in 1968 and production in 1969. The plant initially had a workforce of 250 people. This plant complemented the other existing manufacturing facilities of Capitol Records in Scranton

column1: In 1969 Capitol Records' Pressing Plant in Scranton began phasing out its vinyl manufacturing in favor of the new Winchester plant. Records pressed here include the Beatles' Abbey Road
column2: Simon and Garfunkel's The Concert in Central Park and Richard Pryor's self-titled album. Capitol Records announced in late 1987 that it would end tape duplicating production in the US
column3: in favor of offshore manufacturing
column5: putting more than 500 employees out of work when they closed the Winchester plant.
